(C0.1) Give a general description and introduction to your organization.
CEMEX, S.A.B. de C.V. is a publicly traded stock corporation with variable capital, or sociedad andénima bursatil de capital variable, organized under the laws of Mexico, with its headquarters located at Avenida Ricardo Margain Zozaya #325, Colonia Valle del Campestre, San Pedro Garza Garcia, Nuevo Le6én, 66265, Mexico. CEMEX's main phone number is +52 81 8888-8888. Cemex, S.A.B. de C.V. started doing business in 1906 and was registered with the Mercantile Section of the Public Registry of Property and Commerce in Monterrey, Nuevo Leon, Mexico, on June 11, 1920, which as of the date of this annual report is for an indefinite period. Beginning April 2006, Cemex, S.A.B. de C.V.’s full legal and commercial name is Cemex, Sociedad Andnima Bursatil de Capital Variable. CEMEX is one of the largest cement companies in the world, based on annual installed cement production capacity as of December 31, 2022, of approximately 89.2 million tons. CEMEX is one of the largest ready-mix concrete company in the world with annual sales volumes of approximately 50.1 million cubic meters and one of the largest aggregates companies in the world with annual sales volumes of approximately 139.2 million tons, in each case, based on our annual sales volumes in 2022. CEMEX is also one of the world’s largest traders of cement and clinker. CEMEX, S.A.B. de C.V. is an operating and holding company engaged, directly or indirectly, through its operating subsidiaries, primarily in the production, distribution, marketing and sale of cement, ready-mix concrete, aggregates, clinker and other construction materials throughout the world, and that provides reliable construction-related services to customers and communities in more than 50 countries throughout the world, and maintains business relationships in over 100 countries worldwide. CEMEX operates globally, with operations in Mexico, the United States, Europe, South America, Central America, the Caribbean, Asia, the Middle East and Africa. CEMEX had total assets of approximately US$26.48 billion as of December 31, 2022. As of December 31, 2022, CEMEX’s cement production facilities were in Mexico, the United States, the United Kingdom, Germany, Spain, Poland, Czech Republic, Croatia, Colombia, Panama, the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, Nicaragua, Trinidad

The Variable Compensation Plan available to our senior management takes into account individual performance, as well as metrics that consider their business unit’s, regional and consolidated global results as compared to the company’s specific annual target goals, including certain health and safety and sustainability-related factors. In 2022 our Variable Compensation Plan includes a new CO2 Emissions Component related to our carbon reduction goals that could have an impact ranging from -10% to +10% in the total cash payout of the annual Variable Compensation Plan. Furthermore, in March 2022, we announced that our Variable Compensation Plan was expanded to cover approximately 4,400 employees, eligible for executive variable compensation.
Explain how this incentive contributes to the implementation of your organization’s climate commitments and/or climate transition plan
CEMEX’s transition plan sets annual milestones and targets to ensure that the near, mid, and long-term ambition 2030 and beyond are achieved. Additionally, a set of actions have been defined for the beyond 2030 ambition, including mainly new technologies to capture carbon in several facilities, which are also integrated in the decarbonization pathway for beyond 2030 ambition, in alignment with the 1.5°C scenario. The annual targets defined in our transition plan are compared with the annual performance, and depending on the result, the total cash payout of the annual Variable Compensation Plan can be modified in a range from -10% to +10%, -10% meaning no improvement has been made vs. previous year and +10% meaning that the operation has been able to speed up its decarbonization plans, meeting the expected reductions for the following year one year in advance.

CEMExX assesses annually their main locations exposures to natural hazards with the “Property Loss Prevention Program” (PLPP). This program is conducted by FM Global, CEMEX’s global property insurer, with the collaboration of site experts, mainly operations, procurement, and planning. The assessment provides each plant with a grade score by which all plants can be assessed.
The process to carry out the annual assessment is as follows:
- All cement sites are assessed annually, additionally with certain frequency some other strategic locations with a significant insurable value are visited like officers, marine terminals, warehouses, etc.
- The probability of occurrence and the financial impact if the identified risks are materialized, are evaluated in each site
- To evaluate the probability of occurrence of these climate related events (natural hazards), FM Global gets support from several proprietary maps of windstorm, flooding, seismic, wildfires..., built on information from the NASA, Research Centers, Universities, and other governmental local sources mainly in the USA.
The financial impact is classified in two different terms: “Loss Expectancies-Property Damage”, the “Loss Expectancies-Time Element”. The “Loss Expectancies-Property Damage” evaluate the cost of the physical damage to equipment or infrastructure and the "Loss Expectancies- Time Element” evaluates the production loss and the cost derived from the activities to restore the original production. Depending on the type of event, a recovery time and collateral damage is evaluated with the following formula:
-
LE-TE = (BI * (T/12 months) * % Exposure
LE-TE: Loss-Expectancy Time-Element
-
- Bl: Annual reported Incomes
- T: Estimated stoppage time
- % Exposure: percentage of participation of the specific equipment/building over the total site’s production.
- FM Global also considers proprietary data on historical losses (average recovery time) and research and experience on reconstruction of buildings and/or equipment replacement.
- Additionally, FM Global sets a series of recommendations to mitigate the financial impact together with their “remediation cost” to eliminate/mitigate the risk of a physical damage caused by an acute or chronic climate-related event.
All recommendations from the PLPP are prioritized and evaluated for decision making using three criteria: 1. Financial loss expectancy should the risk occur, 2. Risk improvement ratios defined as the ratio of loss expectancy to the cost to complete the recommendation to mitigate or avoid the risk exposure, and 3. Specific catastrophe risks.
After recommendation’s completion, the loss expectancy-property damage and loss expectancy-time element can be reduced or eliminated, so the recommendation completion is followed-up in a yearly basis and re-evaluated when accomplished.

Description of feedback mechanism
Cemex’s sustainability efforts begin with its Board of Directors and are then facilitated across the entire organization. The Board is ultimately responsible for supervising the overall operation of our company and is composed of qualified persons who provide appropriate oversight. In performing its functions, our Board of Directors is aided by three committees with specialized areas of expertise. Since 2014, Cemex has had a sustainability committee (the Sustainability, Climate Action, Social Impact, and Diversity Committee or the “Committee”), which is responsible for, among other things, overseeing sustainability strategies, goals and programs, evaluating the effectiveness of sustainability and climate action goals and initiatives; identifying the main risks concerning sustainability-related matters and overseeing mitigating actions; and providing assistance to the Chief Executive Officer and senior management team regarding the strategic direction on sustainability and social responsibilities model. The Committee’s members are appointed by our shareholders in our general shareholders’ meeting. To evaluate our strategy resiliency, the selected scenarios are Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS), combined with RCP 4.5 to evaluate physical impacts, Sustainable Development Scenario (SDS) combined with RCP 2.6, and Net Zero emissions by 2050 Scenario (NZE) with RCP 1.9. The worst-case temperature scenario is the STEPS-RC 4.5, which does not take it for granted that governments will reach all announced goals. Instead, it takes a granular sector-by-sector look, considering not only existing policies but also of those that are under development, like the “Fit for 55” package. The SDS and NZE are also considered to evaluate the resiliency of our strategy as more restrictive transitional scenarios and less impacting in terms of physical risks evaluation (RCP 2.6 - RCP 1.9).
To assess our strategy effectiveness the following risks were evaluated under the different selected scenarios:
Reduced market demand for higher-carbon products / Increased operating costs for high carbon activities under regulated markets / Risk of stranded assets, where for all risks both probability and impact increase in the NZE.
And physical risk, so increased business interruption and damage across operations and supply chains, where the probability and impact increase in the STEPs — RCP 4.5.
And the following opportunities:
Increased demand for lower-carbon products and services / New technologies available at competitive cost / Access to competitive energy sources, where probability and impact increase in the NZE scenario and opportunity to enhance reputation and brand value, where in all probability and impact are both similar under the different scenarios.
The results of the analysis confirm that CEMEX’s carbon strategy is in general robust under the three analysed scenarios. With the Future in Action program, we remain committed to becoming a net-zero CO2 company by 2050 and to provide greener products and services for a more sustainable and circular world.
Actions derived from the scenario analysis and how it impacts our strategy:
- One of the decisions we made based on the scenario analysis was to update in 2022 our 2030 targets to the 1.5°C scenario; out new 2030 targets are now to reduce our net specific CO2 emissions by 47% compared to our 1990 baseline in cement and 41% in concrete. - Also, we decided to validate in 2022 our 2050 climate targets to be in line with the NZ SBTIi.
- Also, CEMEX will continue investing in research and development to deliver innovative building materials and solutions to build climate-smart urban projects, sustainable buildings, and climate-resilient infrastructures, while capitalizing on CX Ventures, Urbanization Solutions, and strategic partnership.
- We remain committed to identifying and investing in new technologies needed to achieve our 2050 target, and it will be strengthened in the most carbon-constrained scenarios.

Please explain target coverage and identify any exclusions
Cemex has a trading activity of coke and petcoke in Mexico. The emissions reported under this category correspond to the use of these fossil fuels in the site of our customer and all these emissions are covered by this target.
CEMEX has a hedging strategy to guarantee the coal and petcoke availability for its operations, and the excess volume is distributed to 3rd parties, and CEMEX has also a commitment to supply petcoke to two thermoelectric power plants in Mexico.
As Scope 3 emissions account for less than 40% of our emissions, Cemex is not obligated by SBTi to set Scope 3 targets other than for
Purchased clinker and cement. This is an intensity target and is shown in question C4.1b.
We have also set targets for Scope 1, Scope 2 and other Scope 3 categories. These are shown in question C4.1b.
Plan for achieving target, and progress made to the end of the reporting year
The strategy is to reduce the hedged amount as we reduce our petcoke/coal demand according to our Alternative Fuels increase strategy, so
the traded amount will also be reduced. Additionally, contracts to supply petcoke to the thermoelectric power plants expires in 2023 and 2028
respectively, and we plan to finish them on that date.
For this reporting year we have reduced our sales of fossil fuels to other third parties for wich we don't have a contractual obligation, which in
turn has reduced our emissions in this category.

Please explain target coverage and identify any exclusions
Target covers only cradle-to-gate emissions from purchased clinker and cement. It doesn't cover emissions from other purchased goods and services. This target was mandatory for our Net-Zero submission with SBTi.
Plan for achieving target, and progress made to the end of the reporting year
We have different lines of action to reduce the emissions derived from the production of the clinker and cement purchased for our operations: Purchased clinker from 3rd parties will be reduced due to planned clinker factor improvement by 2030 (reduce clinker content in our cements), which entails a reduction in the needs for clinker. Additionally, we plan to increase the supply of clinker from our operations clinker displacing clinker supplied from 3rd parties (already considered in the own cementitious demand projection). Finally, we will work with our clinker/cement suppliers to reduce the intensity of the supplied goods, ensuring that we choose the most efficient source for these supplies. Currently we are using the average-data method to calculate the emissions, and the emission factors are obtained from Getting the Numbers Right database from Global Cement and Concrete Association. These are weighted average emission factors depending on the country of origin and have a couple of years in delay from the most current data. We will push to obtain reliable emissions data directly from suppliers so that their intensity emissions become part of purchases decision making. We currently have an increase of 5.5% in this target but as we push our suppliers to have reliable emissions data available, we are sure we will be able to achieve our target firstly by reducing clinker purchased to third parties and by working with our suppliers to reduce their own emissions.

DISCLOSURE INSIGHT ACTION
CEMEX and Synhelion SA announced the joint development of a ground-breaking technology designed to harness solar energy to fully decarbonize the clinker manufacturing process. Advancing High Impact Technologies. CEMExX is participating in the Low Emissions Intensity Lime and Cement 2 (LEILAC 2) project, an initiative funded by the European Union's Horizon 2020 research program. CEMEX also has active participation in LEILAC 1, working to develop the direct separation and concentration of process carbon emissions from the clinker manufacture, and will continue its contributions to the project by bringing expertise, experience, and key resources. Rapid Carbonation of Concrete Aggregates. CEMExX is participating in the FastCarb Project, a multi-stakeholder initiative that aims to accelerate the carbonation process of aggregates made from recycled concrete. The National Technical Center of CEMEX France will evaluate in its laboratory facilities the physical and mechanical properties of the carbonated recycled concrete aggregates when used in ready-mix concrete. New Concrete Technologies. We continue working to further develop concrete technologies, admixtures, and novel binding materials that help lower the CO2 footprint compared to conventional cement. Improving Other Cementitious Materials. CEMEX signed an agreement with Carbon Upcycling Technologies that aims to produce nanomaterials with greater reactivity and a lower carbon footprint. All these measures are fully aligned to the sectorial GCCA Net-Zero roadmap which we fully support, as we have been actively participating in its definition.

Since 2010, we have been rolling out CEMEX Supplier Sustainability Program, an effort that extends our commitment to sustainable practices and policies to our business partners through an evaluation executed by a specialized independent firm, including criteria such as Health & Safety, Community Relations, Human Rights, Employee Development and Diversity, and Environmental Compliance (including climate-related topics), among others. As part of our Sustainability 2030 Ambitions, we have decided to refine our former supplier assessment focus and our new plan is to assess at least 80% of the critical suppliers spend under our company’s global procurement scope. By critical we refer to those business partners who can have significant impact on our three core businesses (cement, ready-mix concrete, and aggregates). Specifically, this involves those who could affect the continuity of our operations, involve environmental risks, and/or contribute the highest spend. At year end we have evaluated 72% of the total procurement spend.

In 2021, we increased the number of suppliers evaluated, reaching 72% of the critical group. During the year, we increased our efforts to evaluate a higher group of critical suppliers. Part of the alternative fuels we used in our kilns are biomass. According the The Cement CO2 Protocol: CO2 Emissions Monitoring and Reporting Protocol for the Cement Industry, the combustion of this biomass is monitored in the annual protocol, but it is then not taken into consideration in any cement sector KPI, as it is considered carbon neutral. It is worth to clarify that all the biomass we consumed is always waste-derived, and we do not use any biomass from a dedicated cultivation. Examples of biomass we co-process in our kilns are sewage sludge, peanut and rice shells, animal meal, pruning and agricultural waste and biomass fraction in our alternative fuels (i.e. RDF and tyres). The carbon neutrality of the biomass we co-process in our kilns is also recognized by the verification process in the EU ETS and the California Cap-and-Trade, where biomass combustion is monitored but it is then not accounted as it is considered carbon neutral. Comment
Part of the alternative fuels we used in our kilns are biomass. According the The Cement CO2 Protocol: CO2 Emissions Monitoring and Reporting Protocol for the Cement Industry, the combustion of this biomass is monitored in the annual protocol, but it is then not taken into consideration in any cement sector KPI, as it is considered carbon neutral. It is worth to clarify that all the biomass we consumed is always waste-derived, and we do not use any biomass from a dedicated cultivation. Examples of biomass we co-process in our kilns are sewage sludge, peanut and rice shells, animal meal, pruning and agricultural waste and biomass fraction in our alternative fuels (i.e. RDF and tyres). The carbon neutrality of the biomass we co-process in our kilns is also recognized by the verification process in the EU ETS and the California Cap-and-Trade, where biomass combustion is monitored but it is then not accounted as it is considered carbon neutral. This is also recognized by IPCC Q2-10 - https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/faq/faq.html

EMISSIONS REDUCTION STRATEGY: We developed a "CO2 Reduction Roadmap" plan for all the cement sites that we started to revisit in late 2020 to increase our 2025 and 2030 ambition. There is a designated leader in each Region from Operations and another leader from the Strategic planning side. This effort is leaded globally by the Director of Sustainability in coordination with the VP of Operations and Technology. There is a dedicated resource to consolidate all the information at global level.
This plan aims to identify, evaluate from the technical point of view and evaluate the economical feasibility of each and every initiative listed in each site. According this economical feasibility, the initiatives are classified in short, middle and long term execution. The roll-out in each country started with a kick-off workshop, leaded by Global Ops and Tech (GO&T) and Corporate Sustainability, where the goal is presented together with the available global solutions. The Workshop is comprised of local members from Operations (production, quality and maintenance), Sustainability, Procurement, Sales and Planning.
We identified 290 initiatives including improvements to energy efficiency, switch to alternative fuels (biomass) or natural gas, the use of clinker substitutes and decarbonated raw materials (local availability) and novel clinker development. CEMEX global is also actively participating in the development of CCUS tech. as a potential long-term solution, together with open constant dialogue with policy makers.
CARBON ALLOWANCES: The strategy in Europe and California is to keep sufficient number of allowances in our balance to facilitate the transition to a lower clinker emissions, minimizing the financial impact while we execute the investments to reduce our emissions.
OFFSETS PROJECTS: In addition to the optimization of emissions in regulated installations, CEMEX seeks registration of emission reduction projects that go beyond business as usual and achieve CO2 mitigation at reasonable costs. A particularly good example is the offsetting of all CO2 emissions from our truck fleet in Colombia by investing into eligible reforestation measures in that country. In 2020 we also started to compensate a range of low carbon concrete Vertua with reforestation offsets with our partner NCP (Natural Capital Partners) for Europe and CO2Cero in Colombia.
MONITORING: In addition to the mandatory monitoring, reporting, and verification required by the EU ETS and CAL ETS, all cement plants track their CO2 emissions using the CSI protocol (see also Q12). All monitoring activities are subject to internal control and third-party verification in a yearly basis. SCOPE 2 EMISSIONS: There is a specific department in charge of energy supplies at corporate level, and also a responsible at Regional Level to ensure all contracts and self generation are including low-carbon generation as part of the decision making process when investing or contracting power supply.

Case Study for monitoring our emissions and track performance vs. monthly/yearly goal, so to comply with the systems we are regulated or to comply with our internal metrics:
Situtation: CEMEX needs to have visibility of its emissions performance on a more frequently basis than the annual CO2 Protocol we develop.
Task: CEMEX goal is to daily monitor the CO2 intensity and absolute emissions in a monthly/daily basis
Action: In late 2019, CEMEX included in the DOR tool (Daily Operations Report) a CO2 monitoring for absolute direct emissions and intensity direct emissions in our cement plants. The calculation follows the criteria established in the CSI-GCCA CO2 cement protocol, son consider fuel emisisons as well as process emissions coming from the decarbonation of our raw materials. CEMEX connected the report to the operational databases to perform the calculation automatically.
Result: CEMEX implemented in 2020 a CO2 module in the "Daily Operations Report" for 100% of the cement plants. As a result we get all CO2 related KPIs in a daily basis and for both, clinker and cement production. Thanks to this automatic tracking, the monthly monitoring in the Exco along 2020 and 2021 has been more effective. The new automatic daily monitoring facilitates the follow-up process at site level, as well as the impact of the implemented initiatives.

We continue to develop a strong relationship with our supplier network. Since 2010, our Supplier Sustainability Program (SSP) has made an extensive commitment to sustainability across our value chain, communicating and promoting responsible practices. As part of this global program, a third-party evaluator performs this assessment based on ISO 26000, covering Social, Environmental, Health & Safety (H&S), Business Ethics, Stakeholder Relationships, and Financial Performance standards. Climate related issues are evaluated as part of this assessment to our suppliers. As part of our Sustainability 2030 Ambitions, our goal is to assess at least 90% of the critical suppliers spend under our company’s global procurement scope. By critical we refer to those business partners who can have significant impact on our three core businesses (cement, ready-mix concrete, and aggregates). Specifically, this involves those who could affect the continuity of our operations, involve environmental risks, and/or contribute the highest spend. This is the rationale for the coverage. At year end we have evaluated 68% of the total procurement spend.
Impact of engagement, including measures of success
AFNOR, the specialized consultancy firm we have partnered for SSP, prepares a consolidated report, including findings and conclusions from the assessment and identified opportunity areas, proposing an action plan to close gaps. This evaluation is periodically updated, and suppliers are expected to continuously improve their score (if the company is equal or above the average of their industry-average provided by AFNOR, it needs to be evaluated every 2 years; otherwise the supplier is invited to be evaluated again the next year). This grade is integrated into the supplier’s scorecard to track and reward those that demonstrate advanced sustainability practices. Every year, we recognize our best- performing suppliers of the Program. Process: identification of critical supplier; invitation to be evaluated; signing up of the supplier into a platform where they answer a questionnaire focused in the 4 main topics that CEMEX address: Social, Environmental, Suppliers and Policies. Answers need to have documentation that proves current progress in the self-assessment. AFNOR review the answers and back-up provided to elaborate report and recommendations. Main impact of the engagement and measurement: suppliers have recognized CEMEX’s sustainability priority areas, understanding their importance. As companies are provided with a recommendation plan to improve, when being evaluated in a next round, the expected result tends to be higher than it was. This is how we evaluate the success of the implementation, by evaluating the suppliers’ interest increase and scoring vs. previous round assessment. After CEMEX implemented this Program some suppliers started looking for some opportunities where they could be more efficient and sustainable. Example: raw material freight supplier in Mexico’s central area with a Diesel truck fleet started testing some routes using CNG (Compressed Natural Gas) trucks to evaluate the energy efficiency, autonomy, climate impact and related costs. He increased its CNG trucks fleet to use them in some of our raw material freight routes. In 2022 Cemex also added nearly 200 lower-carbon trucks, mostly concrete mixer trucks powered by low-emission CNG or renewable NG whose carbon footprint is approximately 25% lower than the diesel trucks. Over half of the vehicles were deployed in Mexico, and the rest between Southern California and Colombia.

During 2022, we continued collaborating with architecture and engineering firms to identify and explore innovative ways in which they can use concrete to design and build greener spaces and structures. One of the projects that started materializing in 2022 is the Housing Complex Casas Betania in Barcelona, Spain. This residential building aims to have a class A energy label and it is conceived to meet the criteria of the VERDE environmental certification. During the design stage of the project it was already evident that the materiality of it would play a key role in achieving these goals. The entire concrete delivered at Casas Betania has a very low embodied CO2 footprint and is part of CEMEX’s Vertua brand. The concrete in the north wall has a rigid core and regulates the interior temperature in relation to the exterior. It takes advantage of the material’s inherent thermal mass properties to provide comfort to the living spaces inside. Additionally, through a co-creation process, a special thermal-insulating concrete was designed to eliminate thermal bridges at the openings of the north face walls using CEMEX Insularis Technology. The solution is a precast concrete portico whose purpose is to act as a thermal barrier, preventing heat gains and losses at this critical point of the building’s enclosure. This solution, executed through an innovative digital fabrication technique developed in our innovation center in Switzerland, allows the building to cancel 25% of the building’s heat loss which is typically due to thermal bridges in windows and doors.
We also acknowledge the significant contribution to CO2 emissions’ reductions that the design optimisation of structures can generate down the value chain during construction. Hence, we are working intensively with key stakeholders and clients to teach them how the smart use of CEMEX’s advanced concrete technologies can reduce material’s consumption and absolute embedded CO2 emissions in buildings. During 2022 we have developed a specific plug-in for engineers working their projects in BIM (Building Information Modeling) that allows them to optimize their structural calculations - reducing material quantities in walls, pillars and slabs- and gives them the opportunity to make better use of the interior spaces by, for example, increasing span between columns and eliminating the need of joints on industrial floors. All these improvements and savings are feasible by virtue of CEMEX’s ultra-strength fiber-reinforced concrete (Resilia), a technology engineered to achieve unprecedent mechanical performance and eliminate up 100% of the conventional steel reinforcement in structures.

Describe the process(es) your organization has in place to ensure that your external engagement activities are consistent with your climate commitments and/or climate transition plan
Industry collaboration is essential to accelerate the development of strategic climate action worldwide. Therefore, we are active members and hold leadership positions in global, national, and regional industry associations in the countries where we operate. We aim to conduct stakeholder relations with honesty, respect, and integrity. Through our Code of Ethics and Business Conduct and Stakeholder Engagement Policy, we define our framework when deploying our stakeholder engagement strategy.
It is in our best interest that the trade associations of which we are members align with the Paris Agreement and with our climate action advocacy goals and climate policy positions. To that end, we regularly conduct comprehensive trade association climate advocacy reviews to assess the alignment of the associations we collaborate with regarding our climate and environmental objectives.
We have confirmed that our key associations and initiatives are consistent with Cemex's policy positions on climate change. We base our assessment on a review of the organizations’ publications, social media, websites, and other activities. Additional reviews will be conducted to ensure ongoing alignment between the organization’s policy positions and climate advocacy goals. Upon finalizing the assessment, a climate advocacy review report will be published, and if needed, we will proactively address any alignment areas that may require further clarification. In any case where we may be unable to realign activities and strategies, Cemex will evaluate separating itself from the association in question or ultimately dissolve its membership.
